captions.text:
Hey Vsauce I'm Jake and 
get ready to...

I need to tell you something...I have a CRUSH!,
an incredibly fun and difficult puzzle game.

It has a bit of a tetris feel as you race
to clear matching colors before they fill

up the screen. The higher
score you achieve, the more power ups you

can unlock to help your game last longer.
There are also different play modes like think

and react that will change the way you interact
and make moves. It gets pretty hectic pretty

quickly so for something a little more relaxed,
try Color Zen

There is no timer, no score, just shapes and
colors. The goal is to get the background

to match the border color by throwing different
colored shapes together to clear the way for

the one you want. The game gets more challenging
as white shapes appear that fill the screen

with whatever color you slapped into it, or
black ones that erase the object. Every level

flows into the next making it a beautiful
and continuous experience.

The SIlent Age is an engaging point-and-click
adventure puzzle game by developer House on

Fire. In it you play Joe, a janitor in 1972
who comes across a dying man in the basement.

He gives Joe a time travel device that lets
him go 40 years into the future, to a post-apocalyptic

world. You solve puzzles by going back and
forth through time piecing together what happened.

They are currently working on the 2nd chapter
to The Silent Age so it doesn't have an Ending...

a turn based game where you have to either
avoid or destroy enemies on your quest to

escape each level. As the game progresses
you are faced with more obstacles that are

intent on smashing you, and probably will.
There is also a level builder so you can create

your own maps, and once you get a hang of
the puzzle part of Ending, try the roguelike

section where it throws a horde of enemies
at you and, again, you'll most likely die.

But if you make it through all 8 rooms, you'll
be the coolest kid on the block...block block.

You have to put the blocks into a straight
line which seems easy enough, except the number

of moves you can make are extremely limited
so you have to be really thoughtful when putting

the pieces together. The game throws in barriers
and different colored blocks that you have

to swap to create a really fun and challenging
240 puzzles. For something with a bit more
dimension try

Monster Cube. Monster Cube is a 3 dimensional
match 3 game Every round gives you a randomly

generated cube that you have to solve by moving
and manipulating it before time runs out.

You can break more blocks by doing combos
and the monsters are just so cute. Look how

cute you are. Ahem...lets get serious with
some math in

Sigma12. Sigma12 is another 3D cube game but
instead of matching blocks, you have to add

them up to 12. To get a highscore, you have
to match your moves up to the rhythm of the

music playing. Adding to this are special
blocks like ones that divide or multiply the

numbers, act as bombs, increase the time and
more. It is an amazingly fun game and one

that you might spend dozens of hours playing,
maybe even

Hundreds. The idea is simple, you hold down
the circle until it hits 100. However, this

incredibly simple concept gets increasingly
and sometimes frustratingly difficult. If

a circle that's pressed down hits any other
object, it's game over. And when you have

a bunch of them moving in all directions,
it can get tricky. Some circles are connected

and have to be tapped at the same time, there
are spinning blades that remove all your points

and even ciphers to try and solve. As you
progress through the over 100 levels, your
finger and brain reflexes will hit

Perfection, a game where you have to slice
a shape to fit the given outline. There is

no time limit or cap on how many slices you
can make. Each puzzle is randomly generated

so you will always get a new shape every time.
There are also a few different play modes

that let you rotate or re-scale a shape to
add more difficulty. For something as challenging

as it is beautiful, try this episode's app
of the week...

LIMBO. LIMBO was released on Xbox LIve back
in 2010, and if you have never played it,

play it. And if you've played it already.
Play it again. It is now out on iOS and pretty

much every major platform. In the game you're
a little boy who is on a journey to find his

sister. There are incredibly well done puzzles
that take dying a few times to solve and giant

spiders who want nothing more than to impale
you. LIMBO has a really engaging story, a

beautiful design and is a fantastic puzzle
platformer that you need to check out.

Links to all the apps can be found in the
description below.
I'm Jake and as always, thanks
for watching.

Snoopify is an app that will greatly improve
your life by snoopifying it. Let's take this

photo of Nicolas Cage for example. How boring,
but with Snoopify, Nicolas Cage has turned

into Nicolas All the Rage. What a cool guy
he is now. You're a cool guy, Nicolas. Oh
Nicolas, you are almost as cool as

McPixel. In McPixel you have 20 seconds to
diffuse a bomb and it generally makes no sense

and I have no idea what I'm doing. Hopefully
this works Oh come on. What a load of

QWOP, the infamous flash game from 2008 is
finally out for Android and it is just as

insanely frustrating as ever. Your goal is
to get this athlete to the finish line by

controller every movement of his legs. You
can do it big guy, just a little further.
No...no....NOOOOOOOOOOOOOO

title: 10 Awesome Puzzle Games!! -- App All Knight #15
